White Dubai Cavalli Club Antika Bar 7. BEST TIME TO VISIT DUBAI Regarding the best time to travel to Dubai, the most important thing to consider is the weather. The temperature in different seasons is one of the most important things to know before traveling to Dubai. Other important factors could the prices and how crowded Dubai is in different seasons. But at the end of the day, they are all related to the weather. BEST SEASON TO VISIT DUBAI The best season to go to Dubai is winter. The most ideal time to travel to Dubai is anytime from November to April. This is the tourist season in Dubai when it's sunny and pleasantly warm but not too hot. In winter, you can do everything in Dubai. The winter activities in Dubai are limitless. Of course, this is also when Dubai is pretty crowded and hotel rates skyrocket. Hotel prices are 3 or 5 times more than in summer. BEST MONTH TO VISIT DUBAI December - January - February: Dubai Peak Season In terms of the temperatures, the best month to travel to Dubai is definitely one of the winter months: December, January or February. This is literally the peak season. And, obviously, the peak season means the highest hotel prices and the biggest crowds. Christmas is definitely a popular time to visit Dubai. I think it's an absolutely fantastic idea to spend the Christmas holidays in Dubai. Then, in January and February. It's the best time for shopping in Dubai as you can get terrific discounts on really amazing merchandises. In these months, it gets darker earlier, already at 4 am. Therefore, I recommend starting the day early to see as much as possible in daylight. But you will also find a lot of amazing places and activities that are very beautiful and a lot of fun at night. November and March: Best Weather in Dubai This is right before and after the peak season. The weather is consistently pleasant. At this time, the prices are a bit lower for hotels and there is less crowd in Dubai. I spent a couple of weeks in Dubai at the end of November and the beginning of December. I didn't feel it was crowded and the prices were pretty good. I think places such as Munich feel more crowded literally all year long. I traveled to Dubai spontaneously from Iran at the end of November and I didn't know what to expect. But it was an awesome decision. I told myself, hey girl, you just nailed the best time of the year to visit Dubai. Check out the following comparison table I put together. It will surely help you to decide about when you should travel to Dubai. Month in High Season Average High Temperature Average Low Temperature Dubai Temperature November 31 C / 88 F 20 C / 68 F Dubai Temperature December 26 C / 79 F 16 C / 61 F Dubai Temperature January 24 C / 75 F 14 C / 57 F Dubai Temperature February 25 C / 77 F 16 C / 60 F Dubai Temperature March 29 C / 84 F 18 C / 64 F WORST TIME TO VISIT DUBAI The worst time to travel to Dubai is summertime: June, July and August. Summer in Dubai is just freaking hot, it's a scorcher. Moreover, it can be extremely humid. Thus, the things to do in Dubai in summer are limited. For most tourists, it will be probably too hot to enjoy their vacation in Dubai. However, this is the cheapest time to go to Dubai. This is when the hotel prices drop. The cheapest month to visit Dubai is probably July when the temperature can get as high as 41 C / 106 F. RAMADAN IN 2022 Ramadan, the holy month of Muslims, will be observed next time from April 2 in 2022. If you are not a Muslim, you'll probably not enjoy Dubai this time. It's because in the month of Ramadan you cannot eat, drink or smoke in public as these activities are banned during the day. Moreover, a lot of businesses will be closed during daylight Months in Low Season Average High Temperature Average Low Temperature Dubai Temperature April 33 C / 91 F 21 C / 70 F Dubai Temperature May 38 C / 100 F 25 C / 77 F Dubai Temperature June 40 C / 104 F 28 C / 82 F Dubai Temperature July 41 C / 106 F 30 C / 86 F Dubai Temperature August 41 C / 106 F 31 C / 87 F Dubai Temperature September 39 C / 102 F 28C / 82 F Dubai Temperature October 35 C / 95 F 24 C / 75 F 8. COVID-19 TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS Dubai is open to tourists. People traveling to Dubai are no longer required to present COVID-19 vaccination certificates or negative PCR test results. 9. GETTING AROUND IN DUBAI BY CAR The best way to get around in the UAE, in general, is by car. If you are on holiday in Dubai and Abu Dhabi, don't waste your time with public transport unless you want to drink alcohol. If you are at least 2 persons, it's worth it 100%. This way you'll save a lot of time. You can check car rentals prices and book a car here on the website of Auto Europe. Prices start at 125  (~ 140 USD) with full insurance. The fuel prices are affordable as well. Here are some of the fuel prices projected in Dubai. Special 95: 212 AED (~ 0.51  / 0.58 USD) / litre Super 98: 2.24 AED (~ 0.55  /0.60 USD) / litre Parking is between 2 -4 AED per hour depending on where you park in the city. Public holidays and weekends have the same fare. DUBAI PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DUBAI METRO Riding the Dubai Metro is an absolutely fabulous experience. It's one of the most fantastic metro lines in the world. The metro itself is super clean and modern and it runs without a driver. View from the Dubai Metro - Dubai 7 day itinerary DUBAI METRO CARD NOL CARD: Best choice for tourists If you want to use public transport in Dubai, you must have a NOL CARD. It's basically a chip card that you can recharge. About the NOL CARD System: Where can you use the NOL CARD? You can use the Nol Card on the metros, buses, taxies and trams in Dubai. Moreover, you can use your Nol Card for museums, public park entry, parking and even paying for groceries. How much is a Nol card in Dubai? Mine, which was a colorful card, was 20 AED and included 15 AED credit. I think at that time it was some kind of special offer and I could use it for the metro, bus and water bus. This is how to use the Dubai metro card - Dubai 7 day itinerary Getting in the Dubai Metro - Dubai 7 day itinerary Dubai Metro Zones This is very important to understand. Dubai has 7 zones. The rate you pay for traveling by metro and tram depends on from which zone to which zone you are traveling. There are 7 zones and 3 payment rates. Tier 1 in zone 1: you travel only within one zone or less than 3 km crossing 2 zones Tier 2 in zone 2: you start in one zone and finish in a neighboring zone Tier 3 in zone 3-7: you travel in three or more zones Where can you get a NOL card in Dubai? In all Dubai Metro stations and at certain Dubai Bus stations From RTA Customer Service Centers and RTA authorized sales points From ticket vending machines Dubai Metro Prices Nol Red Ticketdub Validity: Only on one type of public transport Nol Red Ticket fares costs 2 UAD minimum amount to recharge; 7.50 AED 1 zone: 4 AED 2 zones: 6 AED 3+ zones: 8.50 AED Nol Silver Ticket Validity: in regular class on the metro tram and water taxi Nol Silver Ticket fares cost 25 AED including 19 AED credit (e-purse value) minimum amount to recharge; 7.50 AED 1 zone: 3 AED 2 zones: 5 AED (for example Burj Khalifa - Dubai Marina) 3 zones: 7.50 AED (for example Dubai Airport - Burj Khalifa) Nol Gold Ticket This is the best Dubai metro card. If you have the Nol Card, you have access to the seats of Gold Class of the Dubai Metro. It's really worth it. In the morning and in the evening the metro in Dubai can be completely full which is not fun when you are a tourist in Dubai. Validity: in gold class on the metro and tram + on a regular water taxi Nol Gold Ticket and fares cost 25 AED including 19 AED credit (e-purse value) minimum amount to recharge; 7.50 AED 1 zone: 6 AED 2 zones: 10 AED 3 zones: 15 AED I had the silver card: I spent around 150 AED in two weeks and I was on the go every single day. I used the card for the metro, buses, and tram. When my parents visited Dubai, they bought the Gold Nol Card. They loved the Gold Class. DUBAI METRO TIMING The metro is running every 3 minutes during the day and it's super fast. The metro is super efficient too. ABOUT USING THE DUBAI METRO One end of the metro is only for women and children. I always used that. This way you will have an awesome view of the metro rails and the building along the way. As for the bus, I don't really recommend it. Instead, take a taxi. Taking the bus might save you money but you will loose a lot of time as I did when I tried the buses. The other end of the metro is the gold class for gold card users. If I were a man, I would travel there so that I had a nice view from the metro. This is also why I recommended the Nol Gold Card to my parents. Between the two ends, you have the mixed sections for regular cardholders. I tried only once and it was enough. It was so smelly. To go to Abu Dhabi you can use the same card you use in Dubai. DUBAI TRAM It's super nice as well. I absolutely loved traveling by tram in Dubai. Make sure you have a sweater with you when you use the metro and the bus. They use a lot of cold air conditioning and it can be too cold. DUBAI BUSES I don't recommend buses if you are on vacation in Dubai. Commuting by bus simply takes too much time. If the metro and the tram don't take you where you want to travel to, take a taxi. TAXI IN DUBAI Taxi is cheap in Dubai. You can use taxi apps or get a taxi from the street. Dubai Taxi Apps Quite often, it might be more convenient to use a taxi app such as Uber and Careem. But it always seemed to me that they charge you more than a taxi from the street. In any case, in a lot of situations, booking a taxi using a taxi booking app is just so much more convenient. Dubai Taxi Fare Examples 5 km costs 16 AED (~4.40 USD) 7 km costs 20 AED (~6 USD) 50 km: 100 AED (~27 USD) The taxi meter is in every taxi and it's compulsory to use it including airport taxis. Don't make deals with taxi drivers. If you try it, you will probably pay more than the official rates. You can only pay with cash. As for taxi drivers, be careful. They are extremely nice and polite but they can be tricky. Always follow the route on Google maps and know where you want to go. And do stop the driver if he drives you further than you need. Once one driver said: "Oh, I missed the turn, sorry." So I ended up paying more because he had to drive too much until he could turn back. Another time, when I clearly told the driver where I want to be dropped off, he drove two tram stops further, even though he could have dropped me where I wanted it. Once I noticed it, we had to drive a lot forward until we could turn back. Again, I ended up paying more than I should have. Once in Abu Dhabi, I had only 100 AED and the driver told me that he had no cashback at all. And imagine, he expected me to go somewhere where I can change money and of course pay for the ride. The lesson from the story: always have change with you or before taking the taxi, ask the driver if he has cashback if you have a bigger note. As for taxis, there are also luxury taxis: the more beautiful cars are more expensive. MY TRAVEL COSTS IN DUBAI INCLUDING ABU DHABI IN TWO WEEKS This will give you an idea of how much you will spend if you use public transport and taxis while vacationing in Dubai. Dubai - Abu Dhabi: 2 return tickets, 100 AED (~27 USD) Public transport in Dubai: ~ 70 AED (~19 USD) Taxi in Dubai and Abu Dhabi: ~ 120 AED (~33 USD) Water taxi in Dubai: 13 AED (~4 USD) Public transport in Abu Dhabi: 20 AED (~5 USD) In Total: 323 AED (~88 USD) 10. IS DUBAI SAFE? IS IT SAFE TO TRAVEL TO DUBAI? I felt safe both as a human being and as a woman. In Dubai, there are a lot of rules and if people don't follow them, they are in trouble. Therefore, people are more disciplined. IS DUBAI SAFE FOR WOMEN? I consider Dubai safe for women including solo female travelers. I spent the entire two weeks there by myself. IS DUBAI SAFE FOR AMERICANS? Absolutely, it is. It's out of the question. 11. WHAT TO WEAR IN DUBAI? What to wear in Dubai is an interesting question. This question mainly concerns women. To put things into perspective, remember that the United Arab Emirates is a Muslim country. Inspite of the fact that tourists and residents are not required to dress modestly anymore because Dubai's main goal is to attract tourists and expats from all around the world, I know that local Emiratis do not feel comfortable with the way most foreign women are dressed up. As I see it most foreign women completely disrespect the local culture with they are dressed up. However, I personally believe that respecting the local culture wherever we are as guests is extremely important. What Do Women Wear in Dubai In Dubai, you will find women wearing all kinds of things. You will see women wearing Islamic dresses such as abayas and women wearing western clothing. What Women Should Wear in Dubai On the one hand, I think it doesn't matter what you are wearing because nobody will say anything if you are not wearing modest clothing. On the other hand, as I said it's crucial to respect the culture where you are a guest. I personally cannot ignore the fact that I'm in a Muslim country where you are expected to dress modestly. I do respect that. Let me tell you how I dress up when I'm in Dubai. The only places where I was wearing short things are the Dubai Marina, JBR, and beaches. These are neighborhoods and places where most of the residents are western expats. However, everywhere else, I would only wear long pants or skirts and I would wear shirts that do not reveal too much cleavage and cover my shoulders. That's only me. I'm so used to traveling in Muslim countries and I cannot do it any other way. I would just feel that I'm disrespecting the culture. Actually, in Dubai, I prefer covering up also because inside malls, hotels, and the metro, they have air conditioning which is super cold compared to the temperature outside. Frequently Asked Questions Regarding What to Wear in Dubai Do you have to cover up in Dubai? No, you don't have to cover up totally in Dubai unless you visit a mosque. Can you wear shorts in Dubai? Officially, you are not supposed to. However, a lot of foreigners including Europeans, Americans, and Asians are actually wearing shorts in Dubai in every neighborhood. I personally would not do it. Wearing a short in Dubai Marina, JBR and places for swimming, sunbathing, and partying is ok. Can you wear a bikini in Dubai? Yes, on the beaches, in the beach clubs, aquaparks, and in the swimming area of hotels and resorts. What clothes should I wear in Dubai? For hot days, you can buy light and airy cotton clothes that cover your body. There are really a lot of nice dresses for the warm months that are both comfortable and modest at the same time. What Not to Wear in Dubai? These are the things that you should not wear in areas other than Dubai Marina, JBR, beach, and beaches for tourists and ex-pats. Too tight dresses Transparent clothes Tops where your bra can be seen Too short skirts and shorts Dresses and shirts showing too much cleavage Clothes showing too much skin You can; however, wear them in nightclubs, beach clubs and in most hotels and resorts. But I as I said, there are a lot of people, both residents and tourists, who are ignoring these rules. I personally advise my readers to respect the local culture by keeping in mind the dress code in Dubai. 12. ALCOHOL IN DUBAI Dubai is home to nearly 9 million ex-pats and before the coronavirus pandemic, each year Dubai received around 16 million tourists. Thus, buying alcohol in Dubai and drinking alcohol in Dubai are possible in many places. The Dubai drinking laws and rules are quite strict but as a tourist, you will hardly feel it. Officially, drinking alcohol is only allowed for non-Muslims. But in reality, Muslims drink alcohol in Dubai as much as non-Muslims. Where can you drink alcohol in Dubai In hotels, restaurants, bars, and clubs, you can drink alcohol. I've never seen anywhere that Muslims were asked about their religion when they ordered alcohol. Drinking in public and drunk driving Drinking in public places including beaches is illegal in Dubai. Buying alcohol at a store To purchase alcohol at a store, you need to go to a licensed liquor store, acquire your alcohol license and you are ready to get your booze. As a tourists, you can apply for an instant 30-day alcohol license with your passport and Dubai entry stamp. It's totally free. To find liquor stores, just google dubai liquor stores. If you don't want to deal with that, buy your booze at Duty-Free inside the airport when you arrive in Dubai. You can purchase up to 4 liters of booze or two cartons of beer. Drinking age in Dubai By law, you must be at least 21 years old to drink alcohol in Dubai. 13. DUBAI SIM CARD Buying a SIM card is important in Dubai. If you have a Dubai sim card, you can call a taxi, make reservations, and use google maps and taxi apps to get around Dubai. 13.1. BUYING AN eSIM An eSIM makes it much easier to switch mobile networks. Instead of searching for the sim card shop, hunting for a SIM 'ejector tool' to remove the old SIM from your phone, then inserting it into your phone, you can switch to a different network with a phone call or online. Check out the rates of the United Arab Emirates eSIM provided by Airalo. 8.50 USD: 1 GB, 7 days 22.50 USD: 3 GB, 30 days 35 USD: 5 GB, 30 days 13.2. PREPAID SIM CARD UNITED ARAB EMIRATES PREPAID SIM CARD DUBAI AIRPORT As soon as you get to Dubai, buy a SIM card. In terms of prices, it doesn't matter where you buy your sim card at the airport or elsewhere. The prices are the same or almost the same everywhere. DUBAI SIM CARD OFFERS Whether you land at the Dubai International Airport or the Abu Dhabi International Airport, you will find three internet providers there: Etisalat, Du, and Virgin. They all have very good coverage including 5G coverage. Etisalat has the best coverage including the best 5G coverage and it's the most expensive. Du and Virgin are the best in terms of price. I tried both Etisalat and Du. I was totally satisfied with the speed and coverage of these providers in Dubai and Abu Dhabi. DUBAI SIM CARD PRICES in 2023 DU DUBAI - THE BEST SIM CARD IN DUBAI DU Dubai Sim Card Prices in 2023 They offer monthly plans for tourists: 49 AED (~13 USD), 28 days, 2 GB +30 mins call: 99 AED (~27 USD), 28 days, 6 GB + 30 mins call 139 AED (~38 USD), 28 days, 10 GB + 30 mins call 189 AED (~52 USD), 28 days, 20 GB + 30 mins call 299 AED (~81 USD), 10 days, unlimited data, unlimited calls ETISALAT DUBAI - WITH THE BEST 5G COVERAGE IN DUBAI Etisalat Dubai Sim Card Prices in 2023 - Prepaid packages 49 AED (~13 USD), 28 days, 2 GB local data + 30 minutes local calls 79 AED (~22 USD), 28 days, 4 GB local data + 30 minutes local calls 125 AED (~35 USD), 28 days, 8 GB local data + 120 minutes local calls 200 AED (~54 USD), 28 days, 22.5 GB local data + 525 minutes local calls 319 AED (~87 USD), 10 days, unlimited local data + 100 minutes local calls A free Dubai sim card is included in each plan from Etisalat. VIRGIN MOBILE h6>Virgin Mobile Dubai Sim Card Prices in 2023 - Prepaid packages I got this sim card once. My issue was with their service is that I had to wait more than a day to get the sim card activated. Virgin Mobile Dubai Sim Card Prices in 2023 - Prepaid packages 150 AED (~41 USD), 7 days, 21 GB + 30 mins local calls, 20 mins international calls 200 AED (~55 USD), 10 days, 40 GB + 30 mins local calls, 20 mins international calls 300 AED (~82 USD), 15 days, 75 GB + 30 mins local calls, 20 mins international calls 14. IS DUBAI EXPENSIVE Generally, I don't find Dubai expensive. A vacation in Italy, Germany or Croatia would cost you way more than a vacation in Dubai. Yes, you can find the most expensive and luxurious hotels in the world in Dubai but you can also find cheap accommodation such as hostels for 25 USD per night. Yes, there are a lot of expensive restaurants in Dubai but most restaurants are affordable. Average, you pay around 10 USD for lunch or dinner in very nice places. Moreover, in Old Dubai, you can get very delicious Indian food for less than 3 USD. The public transport and taxis are really cheap in Dubai. In Dubai, you can spend a lot of money if you stay in expensive hotels and choose to participate in all the fun activities that I recommended in this travel guide. The limit is the sky. However, if you are a budget traveler, you can easily manage on 350 USD per week or even less. Below, you can see some of the prices I collected on the way. 15. DUBAI TRIP COSTS FOOD PRICES IN DUBAI SUPERMARKETS Supermarkets in Dubai are awesome. They offer a wide variety of goods from all around the world. There are cheap and expensive supermarkets as everywhere else in the world. I've collected some items that I bought in Lifco at the Emirates Tower which is a kind of cheap neighborhood. 1 L water: 2 - 3.50 AED (~ 0.80 USD) 0.5 L water: 1 - 1.5 AED (~ 0.30 USD) 6 eggs: 4.50 AED (~ 1.20 USD) 1 L milk: 3 - 6 AED (~ 0.80 USD - 1.60 USD) crackers: 3 - 5 AED (~ 0.80 USD - 1.40 USD) 5 peaches: 13.70 AED (~ 3.70 USD) 2 green apples: 2.80 AED (~ 0.80 USD) Thai noodles: 1.75 AED (~ 0.50 USD) small package of sushi: 13 AED (~ 3.60 USD) cold coffee: starting at 4 AED (~ 1.10 USD) Macha latte from South Korea: 8.50 AED (~ 2.30 USD) large Snickers: 3.50 (~ 1 USD) If you go to other supermarkets, such as Waitrose, you will find higher prices. They have a wider range of high-quality products from all over the world. FOOD PRICES IN DUBAI RESTAURANTS I'll give you some examples from what I tried and I found absolutely amazing. In Dubai Mall In the food court, a lunch in total can cost around 41 AED (~ 10  / 11 USD) Veggie Indian food: 30 AED (~ 7  / 8 USD) Mango lassi: 11 AED (~ 2.7  / 3 USD) In the Zabaal food court, you can find all kinds of awesome international food. Thai Chili Tempura Hotdog: 15 AED (~ 3.6  / 4USD) Red Velvet cone: 23 AED (~ 5.6  / 6 USD) Total: 38 AED (~ 9  / 10 USD) In the restaurant called Logma: Traditional Emirati meal, Machbous chicken with Karak in total: 76 AED (~ 19  / 20 USD) In Old Dubai In old Dubai next to metro station you will find a lot of cheap Southeast Asian mainly Indian restaurants. Chicken biryani (Indian): 13 AED (~ 3  / 3.60 USD) Milk tea (Karak): 2 AED (~ 0.5  / 0.5 USD) Sweet Lasi: 6 AED (~ 1.5  / 1.6 USD) Dinner in total: 21 AED (~ 5  / 6 USD) Touristic bazar in old Dubai: Pakora in the bazar: 5 AED (~ 1  / 1.5 USD) Milk tea (karak): 1 AED When you order on the street, just ask for pakora for AED. If you ask the price, you might get half a portion for 10 AED. And as for the karak, just pay 1 AED like you know the price already. Heritage village in old Dubai: In the restaurant called Bikanervale Indian food: 30 AED (~ 7  / 8USD) Milk tea (karak): 7 AED (~ 2  / 2USD) Lunch in total: 37 AED (~ 9  / 10USD) In Atlantis Ice coffee take away: 22 AED (~ 5  / 6 USD) TAXI PRICES IN DUBAI 8 km costs 17 AED (~ 4.15  / 4.6 USD) 65 km: 200 AED (~49  /54 USD) FUEL PRICES IN DUBAI Special 95: 212 AED (~ 0.51  / 0.58 USD) / litre Super 98: 2.24 AED (~ 0.55  /0.60 USD) / litre PUBLIC TRANSPORT PRICES IN DUBAI Please refer to section 8. Getting Around in Dubai. 16. Text:	+ The text is in white and reads: "+BLACK-OWNED WINERIES & BUSINESSES YOU SHOULD SUPPORT!"	+ The text is overlaid on top of the image, covering part of the table and the wine glasses.	+ The text is likely intended to promote black-owned wineries and businesses, and to encourage viewers to support them.Overall, the image appears to be promoting black-owned wineries and businesses, and encouraging viewers to support them. messages.content: Dubai Travel Guide: Planning Your First Trip to Dubai Home About Travel Food Wine Culinary Travels Work With Me Contact No Result View All Result Home About Travel Food Wine Culinary Travels Work With Me Contact No Result View All Result No Result View All Result Home Blog Dubai Travel Guide for First Time Visitors! by Nadeen April 12, 2023 A A A A Reset This post contains affiliate links. However, all opinions expressed here are original. If you click through on a link, you won't pay a penny more, but we'll receive a slight commission which helps us keep this information available to you. Thanks! While visiting Dubai last fall I took notes everyday which led to this post, Dubai Travel Guide for First Time Visitors ! I don't know about you but one of the most frustrating things to me when preparing for a trip is researching items all over the internet. I review so many articles to gather enough information to make sure I am prepared for that city or country. Because let's face it, how many of us have time to read an entire Lonely Planet book? (Although I do still occasionally download them :) Therefore, I will continue to write travel guides for my readers. My first post about Dubai included my favorite pictures and was on overview of how I spent 5 days there. That post will help you build your Dubai itinerary. This post is a long list of Dubai travel tips that will cover almost everything else you need to know. So here is my Dubai Travel Guide! Do You Need a Visa to Go to Dubai? No--with a US passport, you do not need a visa to go to Dubai (or Abu Dhabi), which is a part of The United Arab Emirates. How to Travel to Dubai We took Emirates airlines directly from NYC to Dubai. They had a 2 for 1 deal airfare which was great! Emirates airlines has deals often and they fly from several cities across America so I do suggest signing up on their website. They also offer free layoversin Dubai. We met several people who were taking advantage of traveling to other countries on Emirates but stopped in Dubai on the way. You can also fly on Etihad Airways into Abu Dhabi and take a shuttle bus or taxi one hour to Dubai. Qatar Airways is another option. They make a stop in Doha before continuing on to Dubai. Of course you can use US based airlines as well. The Best Times to Visit Dubai is HOT! I know-Duh. During the "winter months", which correlate to ours, the temperatures are cooler with highs in the 80s to lows in the 60s. This is from November to March. Based on these temperatures, this is tourist season in Dubai, so expect it to be more crowded and prices to be a bit higher if you plan your Dubai trip for this time period. However, in the summer months from June to August, temperatures average a high of 105! The Best Places to Stay There is no shortage of hotels in Dubai, especially luxury hotels. You can also check rental sites such as Airbnb. In terms of the best location, you should first think of Dubai as a long strip. I compare it to Las Vegas or Cancun if you have been to either. We kept driving back and forth, up and down the same main road. The most central location, and hence the most crowded, is around the Dubai mall which is where Burj Khalifa is located. At the other end is the Dubai Marina with Palm Jumeirah and Burj Al Arab close by. On the complete opposite end of this "strip" is the Dubai airport and Old Dubai with the souks. Along most of this strip is Jumeirah Beach filled with beach resorts, shops and restaurants. Based on your interests, you may prefer to stay closer to one of these landmarks. Getting Around Dubai Just like any major city and tourist area, there is a lot of traffic in Dubai. There is also rush hour traffic. You should be aware that the work week in Dubai is Sunday through Thursday. Their weekend days are Friday and Saturday. This affects the time it takes by car/taxi getting from one location to the next. Traffic is much lighter on the weekends. Taxis For the best prices use the regular taxi cabs and not the fancy Lexus taxis. Check to see if there is a meter in the taxi and you can also ask what the price will be from one location to the next. For example, we were unaware of an automatic surcharge leaving from the Metro station on Palm Jumeirah to the Dubai Mall. Metro Dubai has a very clean and easy to use Metro system. During the week and rush hour this may be your best bet based on the traffic. However, the day we used it we found it be crowded (no seats available), we had to change trains and wait for long stretches since it was a weekend day and the distance to the metro in the Dubai mall was a long walk! It took us over an hour to get to our location using the Metro so give yourself plenty of time if you have to change trains. During the week the trains run more often. Hop On/Hop Off Buses This is another way to see Dubai and there are two systems available. Both are located at the Dubai mall for pickup and have different routes that take you to all the main areas. Unfortunately, due to Thursday rush hour traffic we were not able to see as much as we would like on our bus. Therefore, if you decide to do this, start early in the morning, do it on a weekend or purchase a multi-day pass. What to Wear in Dubai This is a source of stress for many people traveling to the United Arab Emirates, especially those wondering about traveling to Dubai as a woman. I found this article prior to our trip that was very helpful. Basically, tourists and ex-pats wear regular clothes. The only time I wore a traditional hijab and abaya was visiting the Grand Mosque in Abu Dhabi. I expect that would be the same whenvisiting any mosque. While on the beach I was actually surprised just how skimpy people were dressed or not dressed :)You are also expected to have on closed-toe shoes with pants or long skirts for ladies with your shoulders covered while dining in restaurants in Burj Khalifa and Burj Al Arab. PDA in public Before arriving in Dubai my husband read that we could get arrested for public displays of affection while in Dubai, so we refrained. I later read that holding hands and a peck on the cheek are fine. How Much is a Trip to Dubai? Money, Money, Money! Although I am sure there is a budget friendly way to do Dubai, I found it to be costly or at least comparable to the US. Their currency is called "dirham" or AED for Arab Emirate Dirham. You may see it abbreviated ads Dhs or DH. The dollar bill denominations conveniently have Arabic on one side and English on the other side. There are coins as well. The current conversion is 1 Dirham equals 0.27 USD. But again, once I did the conversions for taxis, food, tours and our hotel, it was equivalent or more to what I would pay in the US. Keep in mind I am a luxury blogger somy activities includedhigh tea at Burj Al Arab, a stayat a luxury hotel on the Dubai Marina and I did some private tours. You can exchange money on arrival at the airport but we noticed a slightly better exchange rate at the malls. And there are plenty of malls. In terms of American credit cards, most places only take Mastercard or Visa. Our hotel and the Nike store in the Dubai Mall accepted American Express but that was it-based on our experience. Do They Speak English in Dubai? We found that most people were fluent in English and the street signs, menus, basically all the signage was in both Arabic and English. This made it very easy to navigate. Come with me on food & wine adventures around the world- Culinary Travels ! Food & Alcohol The food is fresh and it is delicious! Dubai is known for multicultural cuisine and pretty much anything you arewant to eat you will find here. I was excited to try authentic Middle Eastern dishes. There is a heavy Asian, includingIndian,influence to the food in Dubai which I noticed while having brunch at Saffron at the Atlantis resort. Since this is a Muslim region, do not expect to find pork in the restaurants. However, there is plenty of seafood, lamb, beef and chicken. Popular dishes include shawarma (sliced meat like a kebab), hummus, curried dishes, basmati rice and marinated whole fish (I ate a whole sea bass vs a filet while in Dubai). Dates are also very popular. They come in many varieties and you will find date markets and fancy date shops in the malls. Try some with Arabic coffee. Please, pleaseignore all the American fast food places while in Dubai! Alcohol: Tourists are allowed to drink at licensed hotels, bars and restaurants in Dubai. Our hotel fridge was fully stocked! However, you are not allowed to drink in public, including on the beach. Public drunkenness is also not allowed (if only this was the case in the US :) In order to purchase alcohol in Dubai you would need a license. To get around this you may purchase alcohol at the duty free shop at the airport. Things NOT to do in Dubai For more about the "can't miss" things to do and see in Dubai, check out my post on how I spent my five days there. But sometimes it's just as important to get travel tips on "CAN miss" tourist activities. Based on my experience, these are the attractions in Dubai that you don't really need to stress about fitting into your trip. The Top of Burj Khalifa Although crowded, it waswellrun operation. However, I was not impressed with the views from the top. Granted, it was a bit hazy that day but most of what we saw were the skyscrapers close by and the desert. If you have been to top of other buildings such as the Empire State Building or the John Hancock Building, I think you will be disappointed. Friday Buffet Brunch at Saffron in the Atlantis Resort Brunch in Dubai is held on Fridays. I chose Saffron since it was described as a fun day party. It was really brunch on steroids. There was a DJ and more food and alcohol than you can consume in 3 or 4 hours. If you are going with a group, I think this will be fun. If you are looking for a more intimate or fine dining brunch experience, this is not it. Atlantis, The Palm Speaking of Atlantis, if you have seen pictures of Palm Jumeirah you have noticed the Atlantis resort sitting at the end. Although I have visited Atlantis in the Bahamas, after gazing at this man-made island for years I knew I had to visit the island and the resort. We took the monorail to Atlantis in order to see the individual islands that make up the Palm. That part was pretty cool. However, Atlantis was an enormous hotel/resort with people everywhere. There were security guards making sure tourists did not enter areas for the guests and it took forever to find Saffron. But, if you do love Vegas style hotels with the high ceilings, designer shops, multiple restaurants and large crowds then you will love Atlantis. If not, stay away from it! lol The Dubai Fountains The Dubai Fountains are located at the Dubai Mall. They were designed by the same architects of the fountains at the Bellagio in Las Vegas. We waited 30 minutes in a hot crowd to watch 3 minutes of the fountain show. It was quick and not as elaborate as I had imagined. I was disappointed. I have been told it depends on the length and type of the song. There are restaurants with outdoor patios located around the fountains so if you have time sit and watch more than one performance. A Day Trip to Abu Dhabi Abu Dhabi is located approximately 1 to 1 hours driving distance from Dubai depending on the traffic, so it makes a good option if you're looking for places to go from Dubai. There are many popular attractions in Abu Dhabi including the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque, Yas Island and Emirates Palace. If you choose to do a day trip to Abu Dhabi from Dubai you can take a daily public shuttle bus, hire a taxi, rent a car, or do a private tour. Since we wanted to see a lot in a short time, we decided on a private tour. Emirates Adventures picked us up from our hotel for a full day tour of Abu Dhabi. Again, depending on your budget, there are many options available. Whew, you made it to the end! I know this is a lot of information to take in but I hope this Dubai Travel Guide has been helpful, especially for first time visitors. Be sure to read " How I spent 5 Days in Dubai & Abu Dhabi " for more information. Overall I enjoyed our trip to Dubai. It was modern, clean, easy to get around, the history is interesting, the food was delicious, the Arabian sea was warm, and there were lots of activities to choose from. I wish we had more time in Old Dubai and I definitely enjoyed our afternoon and evening in Burj Al Arab, our day trip to Abu Dhabi and the desert safari. Have you been to Dubai? If so what do you think of this Dubai Travel Guide? Would you add anything else? Share your thoughts with us below! For more information check out these websites: Visit Dubai Visit Abu Dhabi Be sure to pin this Dubai Travel Guide for future reference! This post contains affiliate links. However, all opinions expressed here are original.
